article: We all like to think that we are perfect to a fault. And whose fault is that? Not mine. Recently, my husband and I got up at the _ of 4 a.m. to catch an early _ to New York. We were extremely _ , perhaps because we were sleep-walking. And we were all ready when the taxi came to _ us 45 minutes later. It was a quiet _ to the airport. We didn't even chat, because he was enjoying his new iPod. At the airport, the taxi pulled in to let us get off, at which point the iPod guy turned to me and said, "We don't have our suitcase ." "You are _ , right?" I replied, for he _ lied like that. "No. I mean it. Did you bring it down? I didn't ." "What do you mean; you didn't?" I shouted. "All our things are there." " How _ !" I was thinking, "You're always _ to do things like bringing down luggage. This is your fault, _ now, we may _ our flight." I didn't say that out loud, though . He already knew how I felt. The experience showed I had a hard time accepting _ . But what do you think of me? Psychologists think that the best way to assess ourselves is _ the eyes of others. We often don't recognize that we've done wrong. Oh, and that missing suitcase? We went home _ in the taxi, picked it up, returned to the airport and made it through with minutes to _ . Later, while walking along Broadway, I noted how _ I was. I hadn't said a thing about his forgetting our suitcase at home.
